ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a great deal about historical events and themes surrounding empires and how they've changed since the 1800s.

Knowledge about different empires and forms of imperialism, especially tied to the empires from the last two centuries
Skills regarding information synthesis and discussion; also writing
General histories of some of the world's major empires (British, Russian, Qing, Japanese), colonialism, and anti-imperial resistance.

The course gave me broad strokes about different empires and their practices compared with each other. However, the strokes are too broad. The course felt as if it brushed off too much, too fast. I came out with some very broad superficial insights, like "the Ottomans were attempting to modernize more than the Japanese." But I didn't gain any deep understanding of why certain empires did certain things.

The main problem of the course is that it has too many topics. I would cut out all contemporary questions. This is a history course, not a global affairs seminar. Study only the British, Chinese, and Ottoman empires. I would also structure the class around topical questions (military force, economic structures, political legitimization, etc.) instead of around empires to promote comparison. I would also triple the amount of reading (I'm sorry, 150 pages on the entire Ottoman empire is a joke) and instead cut out three out of four essays. Essays are bad for learning new comparative material. Essays force specialization because a student needs to know quite a lot to write insightful 10/30 pages on any given topic.

Class discussions were underwhelming. Almost no one did the readings and just spoke to speak. There should be fewer students (below 15), more selection, and no underclassmen. Professor Westad should also be more active in moderating discussions in an old-school way. I would be happy if the professor had pushed back against students when they voiced flawed arguments and cold-called people to summarize readings in order to force students to read.

Great survey of empires. Research and writing projects were interesting and allowed for personal growth in those skills. Helps with thinking concretely and strategically about how imperial structures have influenced world history.
This is a good class for gaining a macro understanding of empire

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The papers Prof. Westad chose for us to read were excellent ones - I really felt as though I was learning a lot and engaging very much with the text. He's also very good at putting students in conversation with himself and each other, so I always felt confident to talk when I could.

I think there could have been more of an emphasis on frameworks for how we analyze history, which especially would have helped us as we wrote our papers.

Strengths - great discussions led by a great moderator/professor
Weaknesses - only meet once a week; twice a week would've been cool
The main strength is the comparison between different empires. The main weakness is that the course attempts to cover too much.

Strengths: great cohort of students led by a passionate, kind, welcoming professor. Professor Westad is such a broad and deep thinker in these subjects, and he led discussions on such a diversity of topics with so much skill and nuance. He seemed genuinely interested in students' takes and engagement in the class. Weaknesses: would like more feedback on all the submitted assignments, more opportunities to speak with the professor outside of class for insights or guidance on research projects.
It could be improved by smaller class size

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you like to read and just have a general curiosity for history, especially surrounding the building, growth, and fall of empires and imperialism. Not by any means a necessary course for non-global or non-history majors but a great one to understand the history of our world better. A genuinely interesting class in my opinion
Yes. Prof. Westad is so chill and funny and VERY knowledgeable about history. The connections he makes in class make world history click in such an interesting and revealing way.
If the course becomes more focused and demanding, yes.
Yes, definitely. I learned so much concrete information I can take home but also many soft skills like historical analysis and research.
Yes, just start your final paper early. A 25 page research paper takes a long time!
